We Will See You At The Cons!
HUMAN TOUCH® RETURNS TO CES, DEFINING THE MASSAGE EXPERIENCE WITH THE RELEASE OF THE SUPER NOVO X, A STATE-OF-THE-ART THERAPEUTIC MASSAGE CHAIR IN A CLASS OF ITS OWN
LONG BEACH, CA (December 27, 2023) – Exclusively at CES 2024, Human Touch® is set to unveil its latest revolutionary wellness experience with the Launch of the Super Novo X Massage Chair, the latest addition to the Ascent Series line of chairs, originally released at CES 2015. This innovative model defines the standards of personal wellness technology unlike anything currently on the market.
Designed with cutting-edge technology, Super Novo X provides users with an immersive experience via massage capability that expands customizations for both depth control (3D) as well as enhanced mid-stroke speed variations (4D). The combination of these technologies mimics the touch of human hands and has advanced massage capabilities to target specific areas of tension, including therapeutic adjustable heat options for the lumbar region and a unique orbital calf massage that allows blood vessels to dilate, increasing blood flow, oxygen, and nutrients to the user’s tissues.
The one-of-a-kind Teardrop Doors pivot upward, allowing the user to step into the chair with ease, and the mix-and-match door panel and pad set options make it easy to match a variety of decors. One of the standout features of the Super Novo X is its DuoSync with HT Flex S- and L track system that emulates a four-hand massage with an expansive “bend and stretch” functionality that provides unprecedented leg and spine relief, increasing blood flow to the vertebrae and discs and rejuvenating the lower back, allowing you to recover with greater efficiency.
Memory settings are available through the Human Touch App as well as the AI-driven Virtual TherapistTM, an advanced massage technology that allows the user to control the chair using voice-only commands for a tailored therapeutic experience. This smart system listens to the user’s needs and preferences to tailor a unique massage experience with 39 individualized programs. Super Novo X also features Sound by JBL through Bluetooth speakers that can be connected to a compatible device to play music or the built-in suite of Sound Soothe collection for immersive sounds of nature.
Whether it’s targeting specific pain points or providing a soothing, full-body session, the Acupoint® Body Sensing ensures each experience is perfectly suited to the individual by mapping your height for maximum effectiveness. The zero-gravity position cradles your back and elevates your legs above your heart, the position doctors recommend as the healthiest way to sit. Equipped with the Human Touch patented “Cloud Touch” air compression technology, the Super Novo models are considered the best overall compression systems worldwide to provide acupressure to upper and lower extremities at key healing points – ideal for athletic recovery but also gentle enough for simple self-care.
David Wood, CEO of Human Touch, expressed his enthusiasm for the new product: “The Super Novo X is a testament to our commitment to innovation in wellness. This is an elevated massage experience that goes beyond anything we have created before, and the Super Novo X makes that possible right in the comfort of your own space.”
The Super Novo X is more than a product; it’s a commitment to enhancing the quality of life through exceptional wellness experiences. It will be available for purchase at select retailers and through the Human Touch website at the end of Q2
For more information about the Super Novo X and other Human Touch products, please visit humantouch.com.
About Human Touch
Human Touch® is an award-winning leading force in the wellness landscape through its creation and production of high-performance massage chairs, ergonomic zero gravity recliners, and targeted massage products which not only alleviate physical pain, but also decrease stress. Taking a unique approach to design, Human Touch utilizes the top engineering minds, medical practitioners, world-class athletes, and award-winning design teams to carefully craft groundbreaking products. Products include the Super Novo, the company’s flagship chair, which was the first to implement Virtual TherapistTM, allowing the user to completely control the chair using voice-only commands for a tailored therapeutic experience.

Filed under:
CES 2024: all the TVs, laptops, smart home gear, and more from the show floor
By
Jacob Kastrenakes, a deputy editor who oversees tech and news coverage. Since joining The Verge in 2012, he’s published 5,000+ stories and is the founding editor of the creators desk.
Share this story
CES is where the tech industry rings in the new year. Each January, just about every corner of the industry shows up with announcements and previews that set the stage for the year to come. Expect news around laptops, TVs, smart home gadgets, transportation tech, gaming, smartphones, wearables, virtual reality, and a whole lot more.
This year’s show kicks off with a day of press conferences on Monday, January 8th, featuring Samsung, LG, Nvidia, Sony, and more. Then the show floor officially opens on Tuesday, January 9th and runs through Friday, January 12th in Las Vegas, Nevada.
It’s going to be a busy week. There’s likely to be a bunch of virtual reality news as companies race to compete with Apple’s Vision Pro headset, smart home companies will continue to jam tech into more parts of our home (and hopefully get more organized in the process), and there’s certain to be a wave of new laptops, tablets, and handhelds powered by a new series of mobile-friendly chips.
As always, The Verge’s team will be on the ground covering the event’s biggest news. You can tune in below to follow along with the latest.
TODAY, Two hours ago
Thomas Ricker
Unlike LG’s transparent OLED TV, Sammy’s transparent MicroLED display is still just a prototype, but it’s the first time Samsung is showing it in public. As a reminder, MicroLED — first seen in “The Wall” at CES several years ago — has many of the same benefits as OLED (like self-lit pixels) without the organic downsides or chance of burn-in. But MicroLED is still too expensive despite the seamless panels getting smaller and more TV-like in recent years.
TODAY, 7:33 AM UTC
Chris Welch
I’ve looked through LG’s new transparent OLED TV, and seen something special
Transparent display prototypes have had a presence on the CES show floor for many years. They’re a guaranteed way to wow people and showcase the unique capabilities of an OLED panel. But LG has seemingly decided that the time has come to ship a real, bonafide transparent TV that people will actually be able to buy this year. At some undisclosed date. For what’s certain to be an exorbitant amount of money.
The company has announced the OLED Signature T (you can guess what the T stands for) here at CES 2024. The product that LG demoed for press in Las Vegas isn’t exactly “final.” The 77-inch display won’t be changing at all, but the company hasn’t decided whether it’ll come bundled with all the side furniture you see in these photos or if it’ll sell those items separately.
TODAY, 7:10 AM UTC
Thomas Ricker
The Signature OLED T — T for transparent — is a new 77-inch 4K TV that’ll go on sale later this year. It’s not the best TV for the money, but this is something you’d buy just because you can.
TODAY, 3:31 AM UTC
Sean Hollister
I’m a sucker for Sharge’s charging gear because it looks like nothing else, and that continues to be true of the new Sharge 170 model and especially the “Internet Hostkey” in my CES hands-on gallery below. Be warned that the Hostkey comes in a wimpy 40Wh capacity model in addition to its reasonable 72Wh one. Here’s my video with a few earlier Sharge products.
1/4
TODAY, 3:30 AM UTC
Victoria Song
I’m at CES Unveiled, and the Palmplug is a neat little wearable glove. There’s sensors on each finger for hand tracking, haptic feedback, and LED lights so you can have visual cues too.
There’s a lot of potential applications (VR is an obvious one) but the one I found most interesting is TheraPlay. It pairs the Palmplug’s hand tracking with a health tech game that helps stroke patients regain mobility. While the patient gets to play a game, their doctor gets metrics to see how recovery is going.
TODAY, 3:16 AM UTC
Sean Hollister
Here at CES 2024, Hyper, J5Create, and Belkin have items on display with the latest in docking and magnetic charging technology — but sadly, none of it is plugged in. Maybe because we’re still waiting on Windows laptops and Android phones to adopt the tech. (There’s nothing to dock yet, right?)
I’m seriously looking forward to 240W charging and 120Gbps speeds from my USB-C ports, though, not to mention a “MagSafe for Android.”
1/11
TODAY, 3:00 AM UTC
Chris Welch
Samsung’s new OLED TV could make annoying glare a thing of the past
Samsung’s third-generation QD-OLED TV, the new S95D, comes with a unique trick compared to its predecessors: it’s got a glare-free display that the company claims all but eliminates any noticeable reflections. This should prevent annoying distractions when you’re watching the TV on a sun-drenched day and trying to enjoy your content.
Anti-reflective coatings are nothing new on high-end TVs — Samsung, LG, and Sony are all pretty good at them as it stands — but Samsung seems to have gone a step beyond that with the special panel treatment being used here, and it insists there are no negative impacts on viewing angle or color distortion as a result.
TODAY, 1:00 AM UTC
Emma Roth
Belkin made an iPhone dock that can track you around the room
Belkin is releasing a motorized iPhone dock that swivels and tilts to track your movements while on camera. The device, called the Belkin Stand Pro, costs $179.99 and appears to be the first to adopt Apple’s DockKit framework, allowing you to connect the device to your iPhone without having to install a third-party app.
The Stand Pro’s cylindrical base is capable of rotating 360 degrees, while the MagSafe-equipped motorized arm can tilt up and down with 90 degrees of movement. Once you pop an iPhone 12 or newer onto the stand, you can pair it to your device with NFC. From there, you can open any app with a camera — like FaceTime, Instagram, TikTok, WhatsApp, or Microsoft Teams — and the dock will automatically shift the iPhone to keep you (or your subject) in frame when video chatting or filming.
TODAY, 1:00 AM UTC
Victoria Song
Withings’ latest gadget combines a thermometer, pulse oximeter, EKG, and stethoscope
Withings always shows up to CES with a futuristic health tech device in tow, and this year is no different. The company’s latest gadget is the $249.95 BeamO, a so-called multiscope that measures your temperature, takes electrocardiograms, reads blood oxygen levels, and works as a stethoscope to monitor heart and lung health.
The device itself resembles some of Withings’ other contactless thermometers, but it contains photoplethysmography (PPG) sensors, electrodes, a digital stethoscope, and a second-gen version of the infrared temperature sensor in the Withings Thermo. You’re probably more familiar with PPG sensors as the green LED you find in most smartwatches that measures heart rate by shining light into the skin. The sides of the BeamO also have electrodes to enable EKG readings for atrial fibrillation detection.

The new $1,499 Freo X Ultra and $469 Freo X Plus vacuum mops showcased at CES can internally store collected dust within a disposable dust bag, compressing it down into tight parcels that won’t need emptying for up to 60 days.
It’s not quite self-emptying, but credit to Narwal for developing new ways to make automated cleaning tech even lazier.

It’ll be a few weeks until they’re available to purchase, but customers hunting for Qi2 products are already spoiled for choice given the numerous offerings already announced by brands like Nomad and Anker.
Jan 7
Jennifer Pattison Tuohy
Robot vacuums are becoming impressively autonomous, but they still need our help to clean them, like when hair gets wrapped around their brushes. Dreame thinks it’s solved this problem with a new automatic hair-cutting tool.
The Anti-Tangle Tricut brush cuts hairs wrapped around the brush, so you don’t have to mess with those annoying knife tools.
The brush is debuting at CES 2024 along with the new $1,700 DreameBot X30 Ultra. Both are available for pre-order on February 28th, and the brush will be compatible with the excellent L20 Ultra.
Jan 7
Thomas Ricker
Xgimi launches its brightest projector yet, hides another inside a ceiling lamp
Xgimi has two new projectors for the US: its brightest ever 4K smart projector and a 3-in-1 unit that’s also a ceiling light and Bluetooth speaker. Both long-throw projectors run Google TV.
Xgimi says its 4K Horizon Max can produce 3,100 ISO lumens from its “Dual Light 2.0” laser and LED hybrid light source. It’s worth noting, however, that Xgimi has admitted to overstating brightness scores by as much as 27 percent in the past — something it corrected only after facing a lawsuit from Epson.
Jan 7
Victoria Song
Acer is bringing its glasses-free 3D screen to a more affordable laptop
Despite the pictures, I solemnly swear that, in person, that astronaut on the new Acer Aspire 3D 15 SpatialLabs Edition was reaching their arms out to me. I’ve rolled my eyes at 3D displays before, but this time, it looked so realistic that I poked the astronaut’s tummy like it was the Pillsbury Doughboy. I wasn’t wearing glasses, and the whole thing was equal parts weird and cool. That’s exactly the sort of thing you expect to see at CES 2024 on some far-out, high-end concept tech, but this 3D laptop is coming out next month for around the same price as a 15-inch M2 MacBook Air.
To be fair, $1,399 for a laptop isn’t nothing — especially when you consider that’s the starting price. However, it’s pretty dang affordable as far as Acer’s SpatialLabs devices go. Acer introduced its SpatialLabs 3D tech a while back on a ConceptD laptop for creators and then later to the Predator Helios 300. Those laptops are a whopping $3,500 and $4,000, respectively. This is the first time we’ve seen a SpatialLabs laptop in this price range, which opens up the platform to more artists, developers, and creatives.
Jan 6
Thomas Ricker
Jackery’s rooftop tent is also a powerful solar generator
Jackery has converted the humble rooftop tent into a powerful solar generator that lets any car escape the grid for a weekend or longer. Although it’s just a concept on show at CES right now, Jackery says it will put the tent into production sometime near the end of 2024.
The retractable solar panels are said to produce up to 1000W when the car is parked and the tent is open and facing south. That’s enough to generate 4.96kWh per day in the Western US, or 4kWh as you move east, according to Jackery’s estimates. There’s no mention of its resilience to wind, but that’s hardly a concern for a concept parked on ugly carpet inside the Las Vegas Convention Center.
Jan 5
Tom Warren
MSI’s Steam Deck competitor has leaked, and it’s powered by an Intel Meteor Lake chip
MSI is reportedly readying a new handheld gaming PC to rival Valve’s Steam Deck and competitors like the Asus ROG Ally and Lenovo Legion Go. After a brief teaser yesterday, pictures of MSI’s Claw handheld have appeared on X (formerly Twitter), spotted by VideoCardz. (Yes, Claw is the actual name, so get your GIFs ready in the comments section.)
The Claw looks similar to Asus’ ROG Ally, complete with offset thumbsticks with what appears to be RGB lighting. Leaked benchmarks suggest MSI’s handheld will be powered by one of Intel’s latest Meteor Lake processors, a surprise choice given both Lenovo and Asus opted for AMD’s Ryzen Z1 Extreme processor instead.
Jan 5
Chris Welch, Andrew J. Hawkins and 5 more
What to expect at CES 2024
No single event of the year delivers more tech news than CES. The annual trade show is the starting point for each year in tech, giving companies a chance to announce their next wave of products or tease the ambitious, far-out, and often strange new projects they’ve been working on behind the scenes.
This year’s show kicks off from Las Vegas on Tuesday, January 9th and runs through Friday, January 12th, but you should expect news to start coming out as soon as, really, right now. Companies have been trickling out announcements over the past week, and many will try to preempt the conference with announcements in the days before the show floor opens up.
Jan 5
Victoria Song
Enjoy talking to your new voice-controlled smart bidet
For most people, flushing $10,000 down the drain for an entire smart toilet is a bit much. But if you’ve always wanted a fancy toilet, Kohler is kicking off CES 2024 with a more accessible option. The $2,149 PureWash E930 is a voice-controlled bidet seat that lets you transform your existing toilet into a much smarter one. As in, you can now boss your toilet around.
The appeal of bidet seats is that they let you turn your boring toilet into a much fancier one for a fraction of the price. Kohler’s had bidet seats for years, but the difference with the PureWash E930 is that it has Amazon Alexa and Google Home compatibility, which means you can use your digital assistant of choice to activate the bidet spray, warm air dryer, and UV cleaning features. (And best of all, you don’t have to touch anything.) It also works with the Kohler Konnect app so you can set your own preferences and presets.
Jan 5
Jay Peters
Tesla’s first smart home partner is Samsung SmartThings
Ahead of CES 2024, Tesla and Samsung announced today that they’re teaming up on energy management for smart homes. Users of Samsung’s SmartThings platform will be able to connect to Tesla products like the Powerwall home battery so that you can keep track of things like energy production and your usage.
When connected to the Powerwall, SmartThings Energy can sync with the “Storm Watch” feature so that you’re notified of heavy weather on a Samsung phone or TV, for example. In addition to the Powerwall, SmartThings Energy will be able to connect to other Tesla products, including its electric vehicles, Solar Inverter, and Wall Connector charging solutions.
Jan 4
Nathan Edwards
Razer updates Blade 16 and 18 with new displays
Razer is teasing a major set of display upgrades for the Blade 16 and Blade 18 gaming laptops ahead of a full unveiling of the updated laptops next week at CES.
The Blade 16 is getting what Razer says is the world’s first 16-inch 240Hz OLED panel, co-developed with Samsung, while the Blade 18 will get a 165Hz 4K LED panel with G-Sync. Both panels will be Calman Verified and individually factory calibrated. Like the current Blade display options, they’ll show 100 percent of the DCI-P3 gamut.
Jan 4
Jon Porter
Between Asus, Lenovo, and now MSI, it feels like every major PC gaming brand is lining up to compete with Valve’s Steam Deck. MSI’s Instagram teaser for next week’s CES announcement doesn’t give too many hints about the specs or features of its competitor. But it does seem to confirm it’ll have plenty of fan grills and RGB.
1/3
Jan 4
Chris Welch
Sony is no longer abiding by the industry norm of announcing its latest and greatest TVs at CES each year.
The company skipped Vegas and waited until last March to introduce its 2023 lineup. And even then, the lauded A95 QD-OLED TV didn’t actually ship until the fall. Sony is clearly working on a much different timeline than other TV makers these days.
So it should come as no surprise that Digital Trends’ Caleb Denison is reporting that new TVs won’t be part of Sony’s CES 2024 presence. It sounds like the company has made some impressive Mini LED backlighting advancements that will appear in upcoming models — whenever they’re ready.
Sony is still holding a press conference on January 8th, so maybe we’ll get another look at Afeela at this year’s show.
Jan 4
Jay Peters
With the new Remo Plus DoorCam 3 Plus LTE, AT&T’s LTE network can serve as a backup if the camera’s Wi-Fi connection drops out. This isn’t the first security cam with cellular connectivity, but it’s nice to see the feature coming to more cameras.
The DoorCam 3 Plus LTE will launch around late March, with pricing available in a similar timeframe, according to AT&T’s Mike Van Horn.
Jan 4
Jon Porter
Dell’s new 120Hz ultrawide monitors max out at 40 inches and 5K
Dell has a pair of new ultrawide monitors it’s showing off ahead of CES, the 40-inch UltraSharp 40 Curved Thunderbolt Hub Monitor (U4025QW) and the 34-inch UltraSharp 34 Curved Thunderbolt Hub Monitor (U3425WE). They’re going on sale next month, with the larger model starting at $2,399.99, and the smaller at $1,019.99.
Although Dell’s announcement blog post notes that the monitors are targeting the likes of content creators, data scientists, and engineers rather than gamers, both monitors come with gaming-friendly 120Hz refresh rates. It’s a part of Dell’s aim for them to minimize eye-strain. To this end, they both also feature reduced blue light output, and have built-in ambient light sensors that adjust brightness and color temperatures on the fly. The monitors have been given a five-star certification for eye comfort by the testing organization TÜV Rheinland.

LG just made the fastest OLED gaming display yet
LG Display, a manufacturer that makes and sells displays to other companies, is showing off a new OLED display that could soon appear in high-end gaming monitors. At 27 inches, this 1440p panel pairs a speedy 0.03ms response time with a 480Hz refresh rate — making it the fastest in OLED displays so far.
LG’s new screen is even better than the one in the 32-inch OLED “Dual-Hz” gaming monitor (32GS95UE) it announced in December. While this monitor similarly offers a refresh rate of up to 480Hz, you have to toggle the display down to 1080p to take advantage of that speed.

Inside CES 2024: A Recap of the Trade Show’s Most Exciting Tech
CES 2024 featured impressive state-of-the-art tech powering some of the most innovative devices.
Considered the Mecca of consumer tech, CES is one of the most anticipated trade shows of the year. And with good reason, as CES revelations tend to impress. Some of the most iconic CES product reveals include the Atari 800 in 1979, the CD in 1981 and the DVD in 1996, Commodore 64 in 1982, plasma televisions in 2001, 4G LTE and cloud-based music in 2011, 4K streaming in 2014, and more.
However, not everything introduced to the market at CES turns to gold. In fact, most of the tech that captures the imagination with an impressive demonstration fails to capture the market.
This time, techies continued to display their new wares and inventions, including state-of-the-art televisions, smart devices, computers, cars, spatial computing, and more. Spiceworks News & Insights separates the noise from the genuinely revolutionary tech at CES 2024. Take a look.
Best of CES 2024
1. TVs
South Korean consumer electronics major LG introduced its 77” transparent 4K OLED TV, which is see-through when not in use and turned off. The invisible TV, called LG Signature OLED T, also features a contrast setting to resemble a conventional OLED TV, although why would anyone want to do this?
LG’s model also features the company’s wireless tech for audio-visual transmission.
Similarly, Samsung also introduced its transparent OLED TV, a transparent MicroLED, and a transparent LCD one. Of the three, the MicroLED truly deserved the ‘transparent’ tag, not because of its screen panel but because of its design, which omits the bordering frame. Samsung’s transparent MicroLED also performed the best in terms of brightness.
The Samsung MicroLED TV’s one cm thickness and high pixel density also make it an attractive prospect compared to LG’s, except the latter’s product is going on sale in 2024 and is way more affordable.
2. NVIDIA Special Address
Before CES 2024 kicked off, American semiconductor company NVIDIA conducted its three-day Special Address besides making its presence felt with a huge exhibition.
The company announced various hardware and software offerings, including three new graphics cards, viz., GeForce RTX 4080 Super, RTX 4070 Ti Super, and RTX 4070 Super, all of which double as gaming-cum-local AI dev chips.
However, NVIDIA’s broad spectrum of AI software for various use cases has allowed it to emerge as a key enabler of AI and forget partnerships with multiple companies across several sectors, some of which were displayed at CES 2024.
See Mor: AI and Beyond: Insights From NVIDIA Special Address at CES 2024
3. Semiconductors by AMD, Intel
AMD debuted its new Ryzen 8040 series mobile processors with AMD RDNA 3 integrated graphics and XDNA AI neural processor unit (NPU) to take on Intel. Based on the AM5 platform and the Zen 4 architecture, the 8000G series can offer a boost of up to 5.1 GHz.
While AMD’s new chips have the serious potential to dent Intels’ revenue from the Meteor Lake lineup (even with the multi-chiplet module architecture), the company is focused on a refreshed Raptor Lake lineup of five new stock-keeping units (SKUs). This suggests the company expects mobile computing chips to be at the forefront of the semiconductor battle this year.
Intel’s five new 14th Gen Core HX platforms include those for Core i5, Core i7, and Core i9.
4. AI
AI is the biggest thing in tech right now, with everybody wanting to get in on it to improve their products. For others, it is simply a way to make their products more marketable. Nevertheless, AI and generative AI are the talk of the town, and without conflating the two with each other, look at the best AI tools and services at CES 2024.
The rabbit r1 is a new device on the market intended to make human interaction with smartphones more efficient. The $200 device has a unique form, a SIM card slot, a 2.88-inch display, a 2.3GHz MediaTek Helios P35 processor, 128 GB storage, and 4 GB RAM, supports Wi-Fi and Bluetooth, and eliminates the need to perform the tedious tasks of pulling out your smartphone, unlocking it, heading to the app you need to access, opening it, entering the relevant details, and getting the results.
Nope, we’re not mocking it. The device indeed leverages an innovative technique based on a custom-made large action model to perform tasks as a human would as opposed to AI-driven assistants such as Alexa. It accepts inputs from the user through the camera and mic and interacts with apps on the smartphone to perform tasks such as booking an Uber or ordering a pizza.
rabbit r1’s initial two batches of 10,000 units were sold out as soon as they were introduced. rabbit r1 is available for preorder in the U.S., Canada, Japan, South Korea, the U.K., France, Italy, Germany, Netherlands, Ireland, Spain, Denmark, and Sweden.
Speaking of AI, the conversation would remain incomplete without the product that spurred the age of generative AI — OpenAI’s ChatGPT. Volkswagen announced its vehicles would have ChatGPT preinstalled in the Passat, Tiguan, Golf, and its electric vehicles.
Meanwhile, Amazon is also making strides in generative AI. The company showed off its new generative AI-driven Alexa, initially announced at its Devices and Services event in fall 2023. Alexa now derives its conversational skills from a custom-built large language model (LLM) to answer and address open-ended queries, something the previous Alexa Answers contributors-based tech couldn’t deliver.
5. Robotics
CES 2024 visitors also got a glimpse of an updated Ballie, Samsung’s personal home assistant, albeit only in a video. The robot now has a projector that detects posture, facial angle, etc., to project relevant media on the wall, the ceiling, or the floor. Ballie connects to and manages home appliances to deliver a personalized experience and, while the user is away, keeps them updated on the situation at home.
On the other hand, LG also introduced an AI agent intended to provide users with a “Zero Labor Home” experience. The robotic agent features multi-modal functionality to perform housekeeping tasks using LG’s smart home platform ThinQ. Like Ballie, LG’s smart robot connects to home appliances for a personalized experience and is mobile.

Our favorite new products from the world's biggest tech show

Another CES is here, and along with it, our team’s endless march through the halls of Las Vegas to vet the thousands of debuting products eager for their moment in the spotlight. While we didn’t love everything we saw, we did love a bunch of them! In fact, there were 48 products that singled themselves out as particularly noteworthy this year.

Home Theater
The LG OLED T made waves at CES 2024 with its transparent screen.
LG Signature OLED T
The OLED T is the culmination of LG’s years-long strategy to bring a transparent TV to the marketplace. Yes, you read correctly: You can see right through this 77-inch, 4K OLED TV. If you don’t like it when movie characters are transparent, don’t worry: At the click of a button, a special contrast film behind the see-through display mechanically unspools, turning the OLED T from something out of Minority Report into a standard-issue LG OLED TV—perfect black levels and all. Available in 2024.
Samsung S95D
Samsung is running a familiar playbook in 2024, but that's perfectly fine with us. The S95D looks nearly identical to its award-winning predecessor, the S95C, but being one of the only QD-OLED TVs at CES this year, the S95D is one of the best-looking TVs of the show by default. Its dazzling picture sports the same advantages that we've come to expect from this relatively new display technology: bright, bold color, scintillating highlights, and the inky black levels only OLED can pull off. New to the S95D is an anti-glare coating that eliminates bright, garish reflections and gives the picture a pleasant matte-like expression. The S95D almost certainly won’t come cheap, but it’s also almost certain to be one of the best TVs of the year, if recent history is any indication.
Available in 2024.
Hisense 110UX
During a year of impressive brightness improvements from TV manufacturers, Hisense rules the roost with the 110UX that boasts a mind-boggling 10,000 nits of brightness paired with 40,000 dimming zones and 95% coverage of the BT.2020 color space. There isn’t another TV available or announced that’s capable of these specs. The 110UX will run on Google TV OS (as will all US-market Hisense TVs this year), and a 4.2.2-channel speaker system with Dolby Atmos FlexConnect technology.
Available in 2024.
LG G4
The G4 is the crown jewel of LG's mainline 2024 OLED TV lineup, and the follow-up to the best LG TV we tested last year: the G3. Like the G3, the G4 uses an impressive bit of hardware called MLA (Micro Lens Array) technology, which efficiently refocuses light in order to achieve brighter highlights than those of traditional OLEDs. The G4's sure-to-be-smorgasbord of features include a 144Hz refresh rate and LG's Game Optimizer mode.
Available in 2024.
Hisense U6N 55-inch
Hisense's entry-level ULED TV, the U6N, is the most affordable mini-LED TV we've seen to date. It's the follow-up to one of our favorite budget-friendly TVs of 2023, the U6K mini-LED TV, whose 55-inch model cost just $500 at launch. This year, the 55-inch U6N is debuting at just $400. If the U6N performs anywhere near as respectively as its predecessor, it's on a fast track to the top of our list ofthe best budget TVs.
Available in 2024.
TCL QM89
While we certainly didn't have "world's biggest mini-LED TV" on our CES bingo card, we were nevertheless excited to see it. The gargantuan TCL QM89 features 4K resolution, 20,000 mini-LED zones, and quantum-dot color, just for good measure. It's a peripheral-vision-obliterating marvel, even if most of us wouldn't be able to fit it in our living rooms.
Available in 2024.
Laptops & Computing
The Asus Zenbook Duo can be propped up vertically, horizontally, or laid flat.
ASUS Zenbook Duo
While many of the new laptops unveiled at CES 2024 played it safe, sticking to OLED screen upgrades or new Meteor Lake or Hawk Point processors from Intel and AMD, respectively, Asus shook up its Zenbook Duo line with a wholly new form factor. Dual-screen laptops aren’t totally new, but Asus’s refinement has taken things to a new level. Configurable with up to two 14-inch, 2880 x 1800, 120Hz OLED panels that unfold into 19.8 inches of screen space, the Zenbook Duo can be propped up vertically, horizontally, or laid flat for extra real estate. But the Duo’s secret weapon (apart from a semi-competitive starting price of $1,499), is the magnetic keyboard that connects either over Bluetooth or via pogo pins so you can use it like a normal laptop with zero input latency. It even comes with a backpack, laptop sleeve, and a pen.
Available in 2024.
Lenovo's ThinkBook Plus Gen 5 Hybrid
Windows 11 has evolved into a fine operating system for desktops and laptops, but the tablet PC experience leaves a lot to be desired. Similarly, Android OS has matured but still lacks a satisfying keyboard-and-mouse productivity experience to rival what a full-fledged PC can provide.
Enter Lenovo's ThinkBook Plus Gen 5 Hybrid Laptop. It's a 2-in-1 device that functions as a full-fledged Windows 11 computer when the display-half of the device is attached to its keyboard base. In PC mode, it’s powered by an Intel Core Ultra processor with Intel Arc graphics—great for plowing through productivity tasks. But detach the 14-inch, 2.8K OLED display and you have a Qualcomm-powered Android tablet on your hands, ready to take on mobile tasks using all that the mobile OS has to offer, including a full suite of productivity apps like Slack, Adobe Lightroom, and Microsoft 365. It's a rare device designed to overcome its weaknesses right out of the gate, and we can't wait to spend some serious time testing it.
Available in 2024.
Dell XPS 16
Dell’s new XPS line for 2024 is carrying over the beautiful, minimalist aesthetic of the previous gen’s models, but much is changing in screen sizes and what’s under the hood. While the old XPS 13 Plus is being made over as the XPS 13, the old XPS 15 and 17 are gone, replaced by 14- and 16-inch models. Of the bunch, the XPS 16 caught our fancy—just the right size and well-equipped without having too much bulk. It features the latest Intel Core Ultra processors all the way up to the top-of-the-line Intel Core Ultra 9 185H, which includes an NPU for AI workflows, as well as NVIDIA GeForce RTX GPUs (up to an RTX 4070 mobile). Available in 2024.
Smart Home
The Lockly Visage promises an ultra smooth smart lock experience.
Lockly Visage
The Lockly Visage is a smart lock with built-in Wi-Fi that uses facial recognition to unlock the front door—a game-changer for smart locks. Abode Edge
The Abode Edge is a first-of-its-kind wireless home security camera with an impressive transmission range of over 1.5 miles and smart AI detection for motion, people, and cars. Made for the outdoors, the camera is IP67-rated and is waterproof. It works with Alexa and Google Assistant and has a battery life of six to 12 months depending on usage.
Available before Q3 2024.
EcoFlow Delta Pro Ultra
The EcoFlow Delta Pro Ultra is the first smart hybrid whole-home battery generator providing up to 21.6kW output and 5.6kW solar input. The system is ideal for homes that experience frequent power outages or want to use solar power to save on energy costs.
The Delta Pro Ultra is a portable power station on wheels that uses lithium-ion phosphate batteries. It can also be directly connected to your home using the EcoFlow Smart Home Panel 2. Together, the two systems can keep devices in your home powered when the grid goes down.

Available now.
GE Cync Reveal HD+ Full Color Undercabinet Fixtures and Pucks
The Cync Reveal HD+ Full Color Undercabinet Fixtures and Pucks are an exciting new way to light up your kitchen. Gone are the days of using brackets and hoping the adhesive holds on smart strip lights—these undercabinet lights use screws and plug-ins, or you can hardwire them in for a flexible installation.
These dimmable lights are vibrant, offering more than 16 million collars. The design is sleek with a slim profile. The Undercabinet Fixtures come in three sizes, and the Pucks are for smaller areas. Plug-in or hardwired, the fixtures are semi-permanent to permanent, and a maximum of 10 lights can be connected wirelessly, with controls available from Alexa, Google, the Cync app, Matter, or the Savant professional app.
Available in 2024.
Headphones
The real-time biometric feedback features of the Sennheiser Momentum Sport push the envelope.
Sennheiser Momentum Sport
You’d think a Sennheiser earbuds pair would be winning an award for its sound quality, and while we expect the Momentum Sport to appeal to many on that front, what’s really interesting about these sport earbuds are the extra unique features along for the ride. Most notably, the IP55-rated Sennheiser Momentum Sport allows for real-time biometric feedback from a photoplethysmography (PPG) heart rate sensor and body temperature sensor that connects to supported apps. There’s also what Sennheiser calls an acoustic relief channel—a small hole near the driver of each earbud—that helps to lessen distracting body noises such as your breathing and footsteps. Four wings and three ear tips offer plenty of options for a secure fit.
Available April 9, 2024.
Watches & Wearables
The Garmin HRM-Fit syncs your data with your compatible Garmin watch, making it a comfortable game changer in the heart rate monitor field.
Garmin HRM-Fit
Like other chest-worn monitors we know and love from Garmin, the new HRM-Fit accurately monitors and records heart rate and training data for activities such as running, HIIT, cycling, strength training, and more.
It also tracks your usual stats like steps, calories burned, and intensity minutes, as well as running dynamics such as ground contact time, cadence, and stride length. The HRM-Fit syncs your data with your compatible Garmin watch, but can also store data if your watch is out of range.
This device is a game changer for anyone prone to chafing or irritation from wearing a heart rate monitor under their sports bra, and we’re excited to see it hit the market.

Kitchen & Cooking
This battery-powered induction cooktop boasts a more energy-efficient experience than gas ranges.
Impulse Induction Cooktop
You can now switch from gas to induction cooking without hiring an electrician. Induction ranges are becoming the healthier, more sustainable choice over gas, and now Impulse Labs is taking that initiative one step further with its new battery-powered induction cooktop.
This technology can run on a typical 120V outlet, which means even homes that have been designed for gas cooking can easily make the switch without much expense. Less electricity usage, saves on energy bills and benefits the environment. It also means the energy output is more efficient, resulting in burners that are three times more powerful than typical induction and five times more powerful than gas.
This cooktop also boasts a sleek LCD touchscreen, magnetic knobs for easy cleaning, and integrated temperature sensors for a seamless user experience that leaves little room for error while cooking.
Available in Q4 2024.

2024 is the year of electric alternatives. From induction ranges to outdoor grills, many of us are ditching gas for the sake of cleaner air and a more seamless user experience.

With a classic look but plenty of modern features, this grill makes propane tanks a thing of the past. It boasts the ability to reach temperatures of 700°F—150°F higher than a typical gas grill—plus convenient features like self-cleaning and a connected app for easy remote control and monitoring.
This Current Backyard grill also features four probes that can each be independently set through the app, so you can reliably cook meat to the exact liking of multiple guests at the same time.
Available in February 2024.

Smoking is no longer relegated to an outdoor activity, and we’re talking about food here. The GE Profile Smart Indoor Smoker with Active Smoke Filtration is bringing that flavorful cooking method to your kitchen.

In fact, this appliance comes equipped with an intuitive control panel and six presets (think brisket, chicken wings, and salmon) to make smoking a seamless cooking method.
Available now.
Revolution Cooking Macrowave Oven
We've lauded the convenience of multipurpose countertop appliances like air fryer toaster ovens for many years, but Revolution Cooking is taking it a step further.

The Macrowave is also incredibly user-friendly, thanks to the LCD touchscreen control panel and accompanying accessories—including a built-in temperature probe to achieve exacting doneness.
Available in 2024.
Bello water filter and infusion system
Combine concern about water safety and plastic waste with the ever-growing trend of drink systems, and you have the Bello water filter.

Available in Q2 2024.
ExoBrew Craft Gen 3
The new ExoBrew Craft Gen 3 takes the complexity of beer brewing, no matter what type of beer you like to drink. ExoBrew can guide you to create 1.6 gallons of quality brew at home—including cider and kombucha—in less time and with more assurance and guidance than other brew kits.
The creators of ExoBrew have taken the traditional beer-brewing system, shrunk it down to a size suitable for a home kitchen, and added smart capabilities while allowing you to enjoy the spirit of beer brewing. Users can follow prescribed recipes or create their own. You can also source all ingredients from ExoBrew and try a variety of different brews.
Available in Q1 2024.
Barsys 360
Barsys 360 is the bar accessory we didn’t know we were missing, until now. Cocktail shakers will be gathering dust, and if you’ve ever been intimidated by mixing cocktails, Barsys brings the confidence.
The sleek countertop bartender belies its hidden talents. With ports to hold 32 ounces each of six different liquids, you can dispense liquors and mixers in the quantities of your choosing, or select a drink in the connected app and let Barsys do the work for you.
The app displays drinks that can be made with the liquids you’ve loaded into the machine, taking the guesswork out of home bartending. If you use the companion cup, it automatically stirs your drink until you remove it from the Barsys spotlight, which turns green to let you know it’s ready.
Available in Q1 2024.

Ample space and noteworthy speed are two hallmarks of this LG Washer and Dryer Combo.
LG 27-inch Washer & Dryer Combo
Over 2023, our laundry experts have noticed a trend: More big name appliance brands are bringing washer-dryer combo units to market, and this one from LG is the best one we’ve seen at CES 2024.

Available in 2024.

It claims a suction power of 8,300 pa, which is even more than the Narwal Freo X Ultra at 8,200 pa, another CES 2024 debut. While we appreciate higher suction pressure, it’s not the end all be all of a great robot vacuum-mop. Lots of other variables matter, including navigation.

Eureka J20 2-in-1 Robotic Vacuum-mop
We are already testing this puppy in our Cambridge lab, but even without conclusive results yet, we feel like the Eureka J20 2-in-1 robot mop deserves a Reviewed Award, CES-edition.
Two things have caught our expert’s eye. Most robot mops use spinning circular pads to wipe up messes. Instead, the J20 features a cycling belt that allows it to consistently replenish with fresh, clean water, which means it can more effectively tackle tougher stains and your floors will be cleaner. Next, we’ve only ever seen an “add detergent” feature in a competitor, Narwal, and its functionality wasn’t great, but we think Eureka can pull it off.

Tineco Pure One Station
Who doesn’t like a product that makes life easier while doing a more effective job? We like what we see from Tineco on the showfloor, especially its Pure One Station vac, which not only cleans your floor, it cleans itself.
Pull this smart stick vac off its base to suck up dry spills and other debris, and then pop it back on its base. The base will initiate a top-to-bottom cleaning program that includes the dock, the vacuum’s rollers, its tubes, and the HEPA filter. Then you only have to empty the base once every 60 days or so, based on average use.
All the rest of the things we love about Tineco models—incredible suction, dust sensor system, intuitive LED display—haven’t gone anywhere.
Available in 2024.
Ecovacs Winbot W2 Omni
Robot vacuums we’ve got, but robot window cleaners? Not so much. However, this year at CES 2024, Ecovacs unleashes a 6-year-in-the-making upgrade to what we consider to be the market’s first and only reputable one. The Winbot W2 Omni uses its own proprietary navigation system, an anti-slip rolling movement, and a wide-angle, 3-nozzle spray technique to ensure windows get cleaned right to the edge.

Available in Spring 2024.

Known more for its TVs than its large appliances in the U.S. market, Hisense has been quietly inserting its presence with tech-forward iterations that offer mass market consumers great value. This smart dishwasher is a great example.

While we’ve seen auto-dose functionality in more premium brands like Miele, which uses a proprietary detergent disc, this Hisense uses any liquid detergent, measured per cycle demand, and does so at an affordable price point.

Aiper Scuba S1 Pro
Part of Aiper’s new Scuba series, the S1 Pro pool cleaning robot has five cleaning modes and is meant for in-ground pools up to 2,150 square feet. It also boasts an impressive new feature that skims the waterline for debris.
Navigating around underwater using its caterpillar tread, the Scuba S1 Pro moves around obstacles using built-in sensors. When paired with a communication buoy called the Aiper HydroComm (a separate purchase), you can wirelessly control the Scuba S1 Pro and even send it to the top of the water so that it's easy to remove.

Dreo MC710S
In a class by itself, the impressive Dreo MC710S combines a fan and air purifier into one multifunctional device that you can control with Alexa or Google Assistant.
DC brushless dual motors generate faster air speeds and more air volume at 12 fan speeds. The air purifier traps more than 99.97% of particles from common household irritants like dust, pollen, dander, and smoke.
Available in March 2024.
Bio Bidet BB-1200
The Bemis Bio Bidet BB-1200 is one of the first bidet toilet seats in the U.S. that works with a smartphone app. Using the Bemis Living app for iOS or Android, you can access features like customizable wash settings and presets for a personalized potty break.

Available in April 2024.
Kohler Rista Vessel Bathroom Sink
Leave it to Kohler to find a way to flawlessly intertwine cutting-edge technology and elegant aesthetics. Making its debut, Rista, a stunning bathroom sink, isn’t like anything we’ve ever seen—in fact, it's crafted by artisans and made by a 3D printer of durable vitreous China, ensuring uniqueness and a long lifespan.
Available in February 2024.

The TCL Nxtpaper 14 Pro has a matte finish and a number of proprietary blue-light-reducing features that make it easy on the eyes.

The Swarovski Optik AX Visio smart binoculars have game-changing built-in AI species recognition.
Swarovski Optik AX Visio smart binoculars

The ANSSil Sleepinbody-Incline Smart Mattress collects data from the sleeper's body and offers suggestions for optimal rest.
ANSSil Sleepinbody-Incline Smart Mattress
The big theme of CES 2024 is AI, and not even mattresses are safe from this controversial technology. The Anssil Sleepinbody Incline is a smart mattress that utilizes AI and IOT connectivity to create a holistic sleeping environment.

The Owlet BabySat tracks a baby’s vitals in real time with hospital-grade quality.

The eco-friendly L’Oreal Airlight Pro dries hair faster than other hair dryers on the market.

Panasonic Palm Shaver
At CES 2024, Panasonic announced a brand new innovation in the world of sustainable personal grooming products. The new Panasonic Palm Shaver is meant for at-home and on-the-go use, with a compact design to fit in the palm of your hand.

The first Intel processor handheld on the market has arrived in the MSI Claw.
MSI Claw

ElliQ 3 operates on a similar philosophy, attempting to be something of an “Alexa for seniors.” Loneliness is a growing problem for those aging in place, and this capable little device aims to curb that unfortunate reality.
The previous-gen product has an attractive design and bevy of games and included activities, but this version takes those sensibilities to the next level by leveraging generative artificial intelligence and large language models.
The new ElliQ is more capable of remembering details it’s been told in the past, and it will refer back to them in future chats. It can even paint and write poems in real time. This new model is noticeably slimmer, but it packs in more ways to serve an important community.
Available in February 2024.
Lumen Glasses
While lovable and adorable, the guide dog is an imperfect accessibility aid for peope who are blind or have low vision. Not only are there obvious risks to putting complete trust in an animal, but millions of folks also don’t have thousands and dollars and years of time required to get that type of assistance.
Lumen Glasses aim to solve these problems via headwear that combines advanced AI, robotics, and self-driving technology to instantaneously map the world for those who can’t see. The headset understands the ways in which the wearer can interact with their surroundings, then it conveys that information via sound and haptics. The glasses can even become aware of specific locations to assist wearers with shopping, reading, and other daily tasks. In theory, just say “take me to the milk,” and Lumen is capable of getting you there.
We’ve seen devices like this in the past, but they’ve normally taken the form of a bulky harness. This headset is the most streamlined implementation of this technology.
Available in Q2 2024.
AirDrop Gaming Audio Radar
Gaming continues to be a bastion for growth in accessibility, and AirDrop Gaming’s Audio Radar is a great example of that incredible innovation. Using six RGB light bars designed to encircle a TV or monitor, Audio Radar essentially intercepts a 7.1 signal to pinpoint the direction of incoming sounds. For example, if shots or footsteps are coming from the left, the light bars on the left side of the screen light up.
For a more tailored experience across other genres, an included base station allows users to assign different colors to different types of sounds, while assigning the arrangements to any one of three possible presets.
Certain games offer sound-based visual cues via baked-in accessibility features, but this is the most complete hardware-based solution we’ve seen. It works across PlayStation, Xbox, Switch, and PC.
Available now.
OrCam Hear
Hearing aid technology is rapidly expanding, but OrCam Hear brings something truly groundbreaking to the space. Noisy and crowded environments are notoriously difficult for those with hearing loss, as singling out one voice can be nearly impossible.
The OrCam Hear uses a small phone attachment
to take a quick sample of each person’s voice from within a group conversation.Then each of those voices can be isolated or muted within the app, broadcasting only the desired voice to the included earbuds.
Hearing loss can lead to anxiety and social isolation, so devices like the OrCam Hear stand to have a tremendous impact on emotional well-being.
Available in 2024.
Health & Fitness
The feature-loaded Segway Xafari can connect to health apps on your cell phone.
Segway Xafari
Robotics company Segway is stepping—er, riding—into the world of e-bikes this year with the debut of the Xafari at CES.
Designed for off-roading, this bike features a rugged one-piece frame, an 80-mm front and 70-mm rear suspension, 26-by-3-inch all-terrain wheels, a 913 watt-hour battery, and a 750W 80 Nm motor.
Riders will be able to connect to the health apps on their mobile phones, as well as monitor mileage, speed, calories burned, and more in real time.
As a smart e-bike, the Xafari can also perceive conditions around you and make adjustments such as automatically adjusting the power output or turning your headlights on and off. The “all-in-one smart cockpit,” as Segway dubs it, integrates your health apps, electronic speakers, sensor headlights, and an intelligent navigation system on a color display dashboard.
Available in late 2024.
Urtopia Fusion AI-Powered E-Bike
A new AI-powered e-bike from Urtopia is already receiving buzz for its integration of ChatGPT. This dual-motor, dual-battery bike uses AI and ChatGPT to help plan bike routes via its smart navigation system.
It doesn’t need to sync with your phone—it’s self-contained—and you can pair it with the brand’s smart ring (sold separately) to track your health metrics like sleep, exercise, and recovery. The smart ring can also be used to control your bike, to connect with apps like Apple Health, Google Maps, and Strava, and to recommend cycling sessions that will help you reach weekly fitness goals such as miles ridden or calories burned.
Urtopia is known for its visually stunning and lightweight bikes, and this one is following in its predecessors footsteps. Its range and torque are stellar for such a lightweight bike, and the torque sensor aims to make your ride smoother and more efficient.
Available in late 2024.

A Glimpse into CES 2024’s Game-Changing Innovations
As the sun set over Las Vegas on January 12, 2024, the curtains closed on another exhilarating CES, leaving us awestruck with a glimpse into the future. Transforming Sin City into a dazzling hub of innovation, CES 2024 unveiled gadgets and technologies that promise to revolutionize our daily lives. From aiding those with disabilities to reshaping our entertainment experiences, this year’s expo wasn’t just about the next big thing; it was about making meaningful changes in the world. Join us as we delve into the highlights of CES 2024, where technology met humanity, and the future became today.
If you found something innovative that didn’t make the list, tag or tweet us on X (formerly Twitter) or Instagram and we may reshare your find!
1. .lumen Glasses for the Blind
Romanian startup .lumen (dotlumen) introduced its glasses with assistive technology to support people with blindness, a product that performs the work of guide dogs. Rather than a dog that pulls the hand to guide a person, .lumen Glasses rely on self-driving technology to create a sensation on the user’s head in the direction where the person should move.
The glasses can interpret the location of obstacles above or below ground, directing users away from hazards and maintaining safety. Relying on haptics, the technology receives information regarding barriers, interpreting the world around the user and directing the person through sensations, including vibration, touch, and force. This interpretation of the surrounding environment in 3D translates into path planning through algorithms that understand mapping, visual odometry, and surfaces.
The product is expected to be released to the public during the second half of 2024.
Learn more about .lumen
2. Augmental MouthPad
Billed as the “world’s first available hands-free touchpad,” Augmental’s MouthPad is a retainer-shaped, tongue-driven interface used to control devices through Bluetooth. Users control the MouthPad using their tongues to facilitate cursor control, clicks, and swipes.
Marketed toward consumers who have experienced spinal injuries, which make hand control of a traditional computer mouse impossible, the MouthPad features out-of-the-box connectivity for most desktop and mobile operating systems. It requires no additional software and repowers in its charging case when not in use.
MouthPad is made from dental resin. The device relies on a battery that can run for more than five hours. It is currently under development.
Learn more about the Augmental Mouthpad
3. LG Signature OLED T
At the LG Electronics booth, the brand’s home entertainment company introduced a transparent, wireless television named the OLED T. The company is marketing the television as the first wireless transparent OLED TV, which allows consumers to design their spaces without the boundaries of a television that obstructs the area of a room where it is located.
The 77-inch screen features a transparent display to align with any home environment and affords a feeling of open space beyond the confines of a traditional screen.
Boasting a new Alpha 11 AI processor and Zero Connect Box are cutting edge and allow users to enjoy the television anywhere in a room with a cable-free setup. The Always-On-Display (AOD) feature allows content, such as artwork or photos, to be displayed through the transparent screen, which seems to create a free-floating appearance. Users can also choose the T-Bar feature to remain informed regarding news alerts, weather updates, or song information as music plays.
Learn more about the LG SIGNATURE OLED T
4. Mercedes-Benz MBUX
Mercedes-AMG and Will.i.am unveiled their partnership on the immersive MBUX SOUND DRIVE experience, technology that leads music to react to the driving style of the car’s driver. The technology relies on software that aligns “motion and melody,” according to Mercedes-AMG. This effect is produced through blending sensors and software that connect with the car’s hardware to express music according to driving characteristics such as recuperation, acceleration, steering, and braking.
As a Mercedes-AMG partner, Will.i.am applied his music history as a performer and record producer to develop the music experience. Forward-looking potential for the project includes applying MBUX SOUND DRIVE to create an open music platform. This would allow global artists to create music in any genre through the MBUX SOUND DRIVE studio software.
Learn more about the MBUX Sound Drive
5. Acer Predator Helios Neo 18
Acer was one brand that pulled out all the stops for CES 2024 by introducing new products and unveiling refreshed designs on beloved devices. The big news from the Acer booth centered on the new Predator Helios Neo 18 gaming laptop.
The Predator features Microsoft Copilot in Windows 11. A dedicated Copilot key affords fast access to AI task assistance. The device relies on an Intel Core i9 processor 14900HX paired with up to NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4070 Laptop GPUs and a maximum graphics power of 140 W in Turbo mode. It features 5th Gen AeroBlade 3D fan technology to maintain safe temperatures through cooling and Acer’s PurifiedVoice 2.0 AI noise-reduction technology to cancel out background noise. DTS:X Ultra-powered speakers provide an immersive audio experience during play, communication, or streaming. Acer’s Predator Helios Neo 18 includes one month of Xbox Game Pass Ultimate, which includes hundreds of PC games.
Acer also took steps to ensure an alluring design for the machine by featuring laser-etched encrypted codes on its deep black anodized cover. Gamers can decipher hidden messages within the codes for an adventure in Acer’s Predator Verse.
It will be available in the United States this March.
Find out more about the Acer Predator Helios Neo 18
6. MSI Claw
Laptop maker MSI introduced the Claw, which the brand says is the first handheld gaming device powered by an Intel Core Ultra Processor. The device features ARC graphics with up to eight Xe cores and advanced XeSS technology for play across AAA titles. It is manufactured using a HyperFlow cooling system, boasts a 53-Wh battery for two hours of life working at full capacity, and also features Thunderbolt 4 connectivity.
The Claw features MSI Center M UI for easy access to the device’s key features and settings, such as a quick game launcher and instant platform access. It supports the MSI APP Player, which affords access to Windows and Android mobile games.
The Claw was developed for gamers, affording a fresh option with a comfortable handheld design. It features a 7-in. full HD touchscreen display with a 120-Hz refresh rate.
Find out more about the MSI Claw
7. Displace Flex
Home entertainment device manufacturer Displace has expanded its offerings with the launch of its Flex 55” 4K television, which the company released as a solution for rooms where screens cannot be attached to a wall. The wireless product requires ports and it is lightweight. It charges wirelessly with the portable magnetic Displace Stand, which is sold separately. This innovative device is ideal for office spaces and children’s rooms.
A user controls the device primarily through hand gestures. The device relies on a proprietary active-loop vacuum technology, allowing it to secure any surface. New safety features have been added, such as advanced wall-sensing algorithms, four quick adhesives for stability, and a proprietary self-lowering landing-gear system.
The Displace Flex is made in multiple colors and can be placed with other Displace Flex sets to form a screen of any size. Advanced thermal cameras and NFC Payment readers afford shopping options. The battery can hold a month-long charge, according to six hours of daily viewing time.
Find out more about the Displace Flex
Reflecting on CES 2024’s Technological Marvels
As we reflect on the remarkable innovations unveiled at CES 2024, it’s clear that technology continues to leap boundaries, bringing us solutions that were once in the realm of science fiction. Each product we’ve explored today isn’t just a gadget; it’s a testament to human ingenuity and a bridge to a more connected, efficient, and accessible world. As these technologies make their way into our lives, they promise to reshape how we interact with our environment and with each other. Stay tuned to the evolving tech landscape, for what we’ve seen at CES 2024 is just the beginning of a thrilling journey into the future.
